document.title: Construction of normal numbers via generalized prime power sequences

creator.contact: Department for Analysis and Computational Number TheoryGraz University of TechnologyA-8010 Graz, Austria
Department for Analysis and Computational Number TheoryGraz University of TechnologyA-8010 Graz, Austria
Dedicated to Jean-Paul Allouche on the occasion of his 60th birthday

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: In the present paper the authors construct normal numbers in base q by concatenating q-adic expansions of prime powers ⁢αpθ with >α0 and >θ1.

para.p: Let ≥q2 be a fixed integer and =σ⁢0.a1a2… be the q-ary expansion of a real number σ with 0<σ<1. We write ∈⁢d1⋯dℓ01…-q1ℓ for a block of ℓ digits in the q-ary expansion. By ⁢Nσ⁢d1⋯dℓN we denote the number of occurrences of the block ⁢d1⋯dℓ in the first N digits of the q-ary expansion of σ. We call σ normal to the base q if for every fixed ≥ℓ1

Math.text: R _ N * sigma = R _ (list@(N, ell)) * sigma = (supremum _ (d _ 1 * cdots * d _ ell))@(absolute-value@((1 / N) * N * list@(sigma, d _ 1 * cdots * d _ ell, N) - 1 / q ^ ell)) = o * 1
R _ N * sigma = R _ (list@(N, ell)) * sigma = (supremum _ (d _ 1 * cdots * d _ ell))@(absolute-value@((1 / N) * N * list@(sigma, d _ 1 * cdots * d _ ell, N) - 1 / q ^ ell)) = o * 1

para.p: as →N∞, where the supremum is taken over all blocks ∈⁢d1⋯dℓ01…-q1ℓ.

A slightly different, however equivalent definition of normal numbers is due to Borel [] who also showed that almost all numbers are normal (with respect to the Lebesgue measure) to any base. However, despite their omnipresence among the reals, all numbers currently known to be normal are established by ad hoc constructions. In particular, we do not know whether given numbers, such as π, e, log2 and 2, are normal.
In this paper we consider the construction of normal numbers in base q as concatenation of q-ary integer parts of certain functions. A first result was achieved by Champernowne [], who showed that
is normal in base 10. This construction can be easily generalised to any integer base q. Copeland and Erdös [] proved that
is normal in base 10.

This construction principle has been generalized in several directions. In particular, Dumont and Thomas [] used transducers in order to rewrite the blocks of the expansion of a given normal number to produce another one. Such constructions using automata yield to q-automatic numbers, i.e., real numbers whose q-adic representation is a q-automatic sequence (cf. Allouche and Shallit []). By these means one can show that for instance the number
is normal in base 2.

In the present paper we want to use another approach to generalize Champernowne’s construction of normal numbers. In particular, let f be any function and let ⁢fnq denote the base q expansion of the integer part of ⁢fn. Then define

Math.tex: \begin{split}\sigma_{q}&=\sigma_{q}(f)=0.\left\lfloor f(1)\right\rfloor_{q}% \left\lfloor f(2)\right\rfloor_{q}\left\lfloor f(3)\right\rfloor_{q}\left% \lfloor f(4)\right\rfloor_{q}\left\lfloor f(5)\right\rfloor_{q}\left\lfloor f(% 6)\right\rfloor_{q}\dots,\end{split}
Math.text: sigma _ q = sigma _ q * f = 0. * (floor@(f * 1)) _ q * (floor@(f * 2)) _ q * (floor@(f * 3)) _ q * (floor@(f * 4)) _ q * (floor@(f * 5)) _ q * (floor@(f * 6)) _ q * dots

para.p: where the arguments run through all positive integers. Champernowne’s example corresponds to the choice =⁢fxx in (). Davenport and Erdös [] considered the case where ⁢fx is an integer valued polynomial and showed that in this case the number ⁢σqf is normal. This construction was subsequently extended to polynomials over the rationals and over the reals by Schiffer [] and Nakai and Shiokawa [], who were both able to show that =⁢RN⁢σqf⁢O/1logN. This estimate is best possible as it was proved by Schiffer []. Furthermore Madritsch et al. [] gave a construction for f being an entire function of bounded logarithmic order.
Nakai and Shiokawa [] constructed a normal number by concatenating the integer part of a pseudo-polynomial sequence, i.e., a sequence ⁢pn≥n1 where

Math.text: p * x = alpha _ 0 * x ^ (theta _ 0) + alpha _ 1 * x ^ (theta _ 1) + cdots + alpha _ d * x ^ (theta _ d)

para.p: with ∈α0θ0…αdθdR, >α00, θ0>θ1>⋯>θd>0 and at least one ∉θiZ.

This method of construction by concatenating function values is in strong connection with properties of q-additive functions. We call a function f strictly q-additive, if =⁢f00 and the function operates only on the digits of the q-adic representation, i.e.,

Math.text: formulae@(f * n = list@(((sum _ (h = 0)) ^ ell)@(f * d _ h), [ for ]), n = ((sum _ (h = 0)) ^ ell)@(d _ h * q ^ h))

para.p: A very simple example of a strictly q-additive function is the sum of digits function sq, defined by

Math.text: formulae@(s _ q * n = list@(((sum _ (h = 0)) ^ ell)@(d _ h), [ for ]), n = ((sum _ (h = 0)) ^ ell)@(d _ h * q ^ h))

para.p: Refining the methods of Nakai and Shiokawa the first author obtained the following result.

p.text: Let ≥q2 be an integer and f be a strictly q-additive function. If p is a pseudo-polynomial as defined in (), then there exists >ε0 such that

Math.text: (sum _ (n less= N))@(f * floor@(p * n)) = mu _ f * N * (logarithm _ q)@(p * N) + N * F * (logarithm _ q)@(p * N) + O * N ^ (1 - varepsilon)

p.text: where
and F is a 1-periodic function depending only on f and p.

para.p: The aim of the present paper is to extend the above results to prime power sequences. Let f be a function and set

Math.tex: \displaystyle\tau_{q}=\tau_{q}(f)=0.\left\lfloor f(2)\right\rfloor_{q}\left% \lfloor f(3)\right\rfloor_{q}\left\lfloor f(5)\right\rfloor_{q}\left\lfloor f(% 7)\right\rfloor_{q}\left\lfloor f(11)\right\rfloor_{q}\left\lfloor f(13)\right% \rfloor_{q}\dots,
Math.text: tau _ q = tau _ q * f = 0. * (floor@(f * 2)) _ q * (floor@(f * 3)) _ q * (floor@(f * 5)) _ q * (floor@(f * 7)) _ q * (floor@(f * 11)) _ q * (floor@(f * 13)) _ q * dots

para.p: where the arguments of f run through the sequence of primes.

Letting f be a polynomial with rational coefficients, Nakai and Shiokawa [] could show that ⁢τqf is normal. Moreover, letting f be an entire function of bounded logarithmic order, Madritsch ⁢etal [] showed that =⁢RN⁢τqf⁢O/1logN.

At this point we want to mention the connection of normal numbers with uniform distribution. In particular, a number ∈x01 is normal to base q if and only if the sequence ⁢qnx≥n0 is uniformly distributed modulo 1 (cf. Drmota and Tichy []). Here y stands for the fractional part of y. Let us mention Kaufman [] and Balog [], who investigated the distribution of the fractional part of p and pθ respectively. Harman [] gave estimates for the discrepancy of the sequence p. In his papers Schoissengeier [] connected the estimation of the discrepancy of ⁢αpθ with zero free regions of the Riemann zeta function. This allowed Tolev [] to consider the multidimensional variant of this problem as well as to provide an explicit estimate for the discrepancy. This result was improved for different special cases by Zhai []. Since the results above deal with the case of <θ1 Baker and Kolesnik [] extended these considerations to >θ1 and provided an explicit upper bound for the discrepancy in this case. This result was improved by Cao and Zhai [] for 53<θ<3. A multidimensional extension is due to Srinivasan and Tichy [].

Combining the methods for proving uniform distribution mentioned above with a recent paper by Bergelson et al. [] we want to extend the construction of Nakai and Shiokawa [] to prime numbers. Our first main result is the following theorem.

p.text: Let >θ1 and >α0. Then

Math.text: R _ N * tau _ q * alpha * x ^ theta = O * (1 / logarithm@(N))

para.p: This estimate is best possible as Schiffer [] showed.

In our second main result we use the connection of this construction of normal numbers with the arithmetic mean of q-additive functions as described above. Known results in this area are due to Shiokawa [], who was able to show the following theorem.

p.text: We have

Math.text: (sum _ (p less= x))@(s _ q * p) = ((q - 1) / 2) * (x / logarithm@(q)) + O * x * (logarithm@(logarithm@(x)) / logarithm@(x)) ^ (1 / 2)

p.text: where the sum runs over the primes and the implicit O-constant may depend on q.

para.p: Similar results concerning the moments of the sum of digits function over primes have been established by Kátai []. An extension to Beurling primes is due to Heppner [].
Let ⁢πx stand for the number of primes less than or equal to x. Adapting these ideas to our method we obtain the following theorem.

p.text: Let >θ1 and >α0. Then

Math.text: (sum _ (p less= N))@(s _ q * floor@(alpha * p ^ theta)) = ((q - 1) / 2) * pi * N * (logarithm _ q)@(N ^ theta) + O * pi * N

p.text: where the sum runs over the primes and the implicit O-constant may depend on q and θ.

para.p: With simple modifications Theorem can be extended to completely q-additive functions replacing sq.

The proof of the two theorems is divided in three parts. In the following section we rewrite both statements and state the central theorem, which combines them and which we prove in the rest of the paper. In Section we present all the tools we need in the proof of the central theorem. Finally, in Section we proof the theorem.
Throughout the paper, an interval denotes a set

Math.text: formulae@(I = open-closed-interval@(alpha, beta) = conditional-set@(x, alpha less x less= beta), list@([with], beta) > alpha >= 1 / 2)

para.p: We will often subdivide a interval into smaller ones. In particular we use the observation that if ≪log/βαlogN, then αβ is the union of, say, s intervals of the type γγ1 with ≪slogN and ≤γ1⁢2γ. Given any complex function F on I, we have

Math.text: absolute-value@((sum _ (x element-of I))@(F * x)) lessless logarithm@(N) * absolute-value@((sum _ (gamma less x less= gamma _ 1))@(F * x))

para.p: for some such γγ1.

In the proof p will always denote a prime. We fix the block ⁢d1⋯dℓ and write ⁢N⁢fp for the number of occurrences of this block in the q-ary expansion of ⁢fp. By ⁢ℓm we denote the length of the q-ary expansion of an integer m.
In the first step we want to get rid of the blocks that may occur between two expansions. To this end we define an integer N by

Math.text: (sum _ (p less= N - 1))@(ell * floor@(p ^ theta)) less L less= (sum _ (p less= N))@(ell * floor@(p ^ theta))

para.p: where ∑ indicates that the sum runs over all primes. Thus we get that

Math.text: L = (sum _ (p less= N))@(ell * floor@(p ^ theta)) + O * pi * N + O * theta * (logarithm _ q)@(N) = (theta / logarithm@(q)) * N + O * (N / logarithm@(N))

para.p: Here we have used the prime number theorem in the form

Math.text: pi * x = Li * x + O * (x / (logarithm@(x)) ^ G)

para.p: where G is an arbitrary positive constant and

Math.text: Li * x = ((integral _ 2) ^ x)@((d * t) / logarithm@(t))

para.p: Let ⁢Nn⁢d1⋯dℓ be the number of occurrences of the block ⁢d1⋯dℓ in the expansion of n. Since we have fixed the block ⁢d1⋯dℓ we will write =⁢Nn⁢Nn⁢d1⋯dℓ for short. Then () implies that

Math.text: absolute-value@(N * list@(tau _ q * x ^ theta, d _ 1 * cdots * d _ ell, L) - (sum _ (p less= N))@(N * p ^ theta)) lessless L / logarithm@(L)

para.p: For the next step we collect all the values that have a certain length of expansion. Let j0 be a sufficiently large integer. Then for each integer ≥jj0 we get that there exists an Nj such that

Math.text: q ^ (j - 2) less= f * N _ j less q ^ (j - 1) less= f * (N _ j + 1) less q ^ j

para.p: We note that this is possible since f asymptotically grows as its leading coefficient. This implies that

Math.text: N _ j asymptotically-equals q ^ (j / beta)

para.p: Furthermore for ≥Nqj0 we set J to be the greatest length of the q-ary expansions of ⁢fp over the primes ≤pN, i.e.,

Math.text: J assign (maximum _ (p less= N))@(ell * floor@(f * p)) = (logarithm _ q)@(f * N) + O * 1 asymptotically-equals logarithm@(N)

para.p: In the next step we want to perform the counting by adding the leading zeroes to the expansion of ⁢fp. For N-j1<p≤Nj we may write ⁢fp in q-ary expansion, i.e.,

Then we denote by ⁢N*⁢fp the number of occurrences of the block d1…dℓ in the string ⁢0⋯0b-j1b-j2⋯b1b0, where we filled up the expansion with zeroes such that it has length J. The error of doing so can be estimated by

Math.tex: \begin{split}0&\leq\sum_{p\leq N}\mathcal{N}^{*}(f(p))-\sum_{p\leq N}\mathcal{% N}(f(p))\\ &\leq\sum_{j=j_{0}+1}^{J-1}(J-j)\left(\pi(N_{j+1})-\pi(N_{j})\right)+\mathcal{% O}(1)\\ &\leq\sum_{j=j_{0}+2}^{J}\pi(N_{j})+\mathcal{O}(1)\ll\sum_{j=j_{0}+2}^{J}\frac% {q^{j/\beta}}{j}\ll\frac{N}{\log N}\ll\frac{L}{\log L}.\\ \end{split}
Math.text: 0 less= (sum _ (p less= N))@(N ^ * * f * p) - (sum _ (p less= N))@(N * f * p) less= ((sum _ (j = j _ 0 + 1)) ^ (J - 1))@((J - j) * (pi * N _ (j + 1) - pi * N _ j)) + O * 1 less= ((sum _ (j = j _ 0 + 2)) ^ J)@(pi * N _ j) + O * 1 lessless ((sum _ (j = j _ 0 + 2)) ^ J)@(q ^ (j / beta) / j) lessless N / logarithm@(N) lessless L / logarithm@(L)

para.p: In the following two sections we will estimate this sum of indicator functions in order to prove the following proposition.

p.text: Let >θ1 and >α0. Then

Math.text: (sum _ (p less= N))@(N ^ * * floor@(alpha * p ^ theta)) = q ^ (- k) * pi * N * (logarithm _ q)@(N ^ theta) + O * (N / logarithm@(N))

para.p: We insert () into () and get the desired result. ∎
For this proof we have to rewrite the statement. In particular, we use that the sum of digits function counts the number of 1s, 2s, etc. and assigns weights to them, i.e.,

Math.text: s _ q * n = ((sum _ (d = 0)) ^ (q - 1))@((d cdot N) * list@(n, d))

para.p: Thus

Math.text: (sum _ (p less= N))@(s _ q * floor@(p ^ theta)) = (sum _ (p less= N))@(((sum _ (d = 0)) ^ (q - 1))@((d cdot N) * p ^ theta)) = (sum _ (p less= N))@(((sum _ (d = 0)) ^ (q - 1))@((d cdot N ^ *) * p ^ theta)) + O * (N / logarithm@(N))
(sum _ (p less= N))@(s _ q * floor@(p ^ theta))
absent = ((q - 1) / 2) * pi * N * (logarithm _ q)@(N ^ theta) + O * (N / logarithm@(N))
absent = ((q - 1) / 2) * pi * N * (logarithm _ q)@(N ^ theta) + O * (N / logarithm@(N))

para.p: and the theorem follows. ∎

In this section we want to present all the tools we need on the way of proof of Proposition . We start with an estimation which essentially goes back to Vinogradov. This will provide us with Fourier expansions for the indicator functions used in the proof. As usual given a real number y, the expression ⁢ey will stand for exp⁢2πiy.

p.text: Let α, β, Δ be real numbers satisfying

Math.text: formulae@(0 less Delta less 1 / 2, Delta less= beta - alpha less= 1 - Delta)

p.text: Then there exists a periodic function ⁢ψx with period 1, satisfying

Math.text: psi * x = 1

p.text: in the interval

Math.text: alpha + (1 / 2) * Delta less= x less= beta - (1 / 2) * Delta
psi * x = 0

p.text: in the interval

Math.text: beta + (1 / 2) * Delta less= x less= (1 + alpha) - (1 / 2) * Delta
0 less= psi * x less= 1

p.text: in the remainder of the interval

Math.text: alpha - (1 / 2) * Delta less= x less= (1 + alpha) - (1 / 2) * Delta
psi * x

p.text: has a Fourier series expansion of the form

Math.text: psi * x = (beta - alpha) + ((sum _ (list@(nu = - infinity, nu not-equals 0))) ^ infinity)@(A * nu * e * nu * x)

p.text: where

Math.text: absolute-value@(A * nu) lessless minimum@(vector@(1 / nu, beta - alpha, 1 / (nu ^ 2 * Delta)))

para.p: After we have transformed the sums under consideration into exponential sums we want to split the interval by the following lemma.

p.text: Let =Iab be an interval and F be a complex function defined on I. If ≪log/baL, then I is the union of ℓ intervals of the type cd with ≪ℓL and ≤d⁢2c. Furthermore we have

Math.text: absolute-value@((sum _ (n element-of I))@(F * n)) lessless L * absolute-value@((sum _ (n element-of open-closed-interval@(c, d)))@(F * n))

p.text: for some such cd.

para.p: For =i1…ℓ let Ii be the ℓ splitting intervals. Then

Math.text: absolute-value@((sum _ (n element-of I))@(F * n)) = absolute-value@(((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ ell)@((sum _ (n element-of I _ i))@(F * n))) less= ell * (maximum _ (1 less= i less= ell))@(absolute-value@((sum _ (n element-of I _ i))@(F * n))) lessless L * absolute-value@((sum _ (n element-of I _ i))@(F * n))

absolute-value@((sum _ (n element-of I))@(F * n)) = absolute-value@(((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ ell)@((sum _ (n element-of I _ i))@(F * n))) less= ell * (maximum _ (1 less= i less= ell))@(absolute-value@((sum _ (n element-of I _ i))@(F * n))) lessless L * absolute-value@((sum _ (n element-of I _ i))@(F * n))

para.p: We will apply the following lemma in order to estimate the occurring exponential sums provided that the coefficients are very small. This corresponds to the case of the most significant digits in the expansion.

p.text: Let ⁢Fx be a real function, k times differentiable, and satisfying ⁢Fkx≥λ>0 throughout the interval ab. Then

Math.text: absolute-value@(((integral _ a) ^ b)@(e * F * x * d * x)) less= c * k * lambda ^ (- 1 / k)

para.p: A standard tool for estimating exponential sums over the primes is Vaughan’s identity. In order to apply this identity we have to rewrite the exponential sum into a normal one having von Mangoldt’s function as weights. Therefore let Λ denote von Mangoldt’s function, i.e.,

Math.text: Lambda * n = cases[[logarithm@(p), [if =npk for some prime p and an integer ≥k1;]], [0, [otherwise]]]

XMCell.XMText: if =npk for some prime p and an integer ≥k1;

para.p: In the next step we may subdivide this weighted exponential sum into several sums of Type I and II. In particular, let ≥P2 and ≤P1⁢2P, then we define Type I and Type II sums by the expressions

Math.text: list@((sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(a _ x * (sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(f * x * y)), [Type I])
list@((sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(a _ x * (sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(f * x * y)), [Type I])
(sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(a _ x * (sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(logarithm@(y) * f * x * y))
(sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(a _ x * (sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(logarithm@(y) * f * x * y))
list@((sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(a _ x * (sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(b _ y * f * x * y)), [Type II])
list@((sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(a _ x * (sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(b _ y * f * x * y)), [Type II])

para.p: with ≤X1⁢2X, ≤Y1⁢2Y, ≪axPε, ≪byPε for every >ε0 and

Math.text: P lessless X * Y lessless P

para.p: respectively. The following lemma provides the central tool for the subdivision of the weighted exponential sum.

p.text: Let ⁢fn be a complex valued function and ≥P2, ≤P1⁢2P. Furthermore let U, V, and Z be positive numbers satisfying

Math.text: 2 less= U less V less= Z less= P
formulae@(U ^ 2 less= Z, formulae@(128 * U * Z ^ 2 less= P _ 1, 2 ^ 18 * P _ 1 less= V ^ 3))

p.text: Then the sum

Math.text: (sum _ (P less= n less= P _ 1))@(Lambda * n * f * n)

p.text: may be decomposed into ≪logP6 sums, each of which is either a Type I sum with ≥YZ or a Type II sum with U≤Y≤V.

para.p: The next tool is an estimation for the exponential sum. After subdividing the weighted exponential sum we use Vinogradov’s method in order to estimate the occurring unweighted exponential sums.

p.text: Let k, P and N be integers such that ≥k2, 2≤N≤P. Let ⁢gx be real and have continuous derivatives up to the +k1th order in +P1+PN; let 0<λ</1⁢2c0+k1 and
or the same for -⁢g+k1x, and let

Math.text: N ^ ((- k - 1) + rho) less= lambda less= N ^ (- 1)

p.text: with 0<ρ≤k. Then

Math.text: ((sum _ (n = P + 1)) ^ (P + N))@(e * g * n) lessless N ^ (1 - eta)

p.text: where

Math.text: formulae@(eta = rho / (16 * (k + 1) * L), formulae@(L = 1 + floor@((1 / 4) * k * (k + 1) + k * R), R = 1 + floor@(logarithm@((1 / rho) * k * (k + 1) ^ 2) / (- logarithm@(1 - 1 / k)))))

para.p: We will apply the estimates of the preceding sections in order to estimate the exponential sums occurring in the proof. We will proceed in four steps.
In the first step we use a method of Vinogradov [] in order to rewrite the counting function into the estimation of exponential sums. Then we will distinguish two cases in the following two steps.

First we assume that the we are interested in a block which occurs among the most significant digits. This corresponds to a very small coefficient in the exponential sum and we may use the method of van der Corput (cf. []).
For the blocks occurring among the least significant digits we apply Vaughan’s identity together with ideas from a recent paper by Bergelson et al. [].
Finally we combine the estimates of the last two steps in order to end the proof.
In this proof, the letter p will always denote a prime and we set :=⁢fx⁢αxθ for short. Furthermore we set

Math.text: delta assign minimum@(open-interval@(1 / 4, 1 - theta))

para.p: Throughout the rest of the paper we fix a block ⁢d1⋯dℓ. In order to count the occurrences of this block in the q-ary expansion of ⁢fp (2≤p≤P) we define the indicator function

Math.text: I * t = cases[[1, [if ] * ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ ell)@(d _ i * q ^ (- i)) less= t - floor@(t) less ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ ell)@(d _ i * q ^ (- i)) + q ^ (- ell)], [0, [otherwise;]]]
I * t = cases[[1, [if ] * ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ ell)@(d _ i * q ^ (- i)) less= t - floor@(t) less ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ ell)@(d _ i * q ^ (- i)) + q ^ (- ell)], [0, [otherwise;]]]

para.p: which is a 1-periodic function. Indeed, we have

Math.text: I * q ^ (- j) * f * n = 1 Longleftrightarrow d _ 1 * cdots * d _ ell = b _ (j - 1) * cdots * b _ (j - ell)

para.p: Thus we can write our block counting function as follows
Following Nakai and Shiokawa [] we want to approximate I from above and from below by two 1-periodic functions having small Fourier coefficients. In particular, we set =HN/δ3 and

Math.text: formulae@(alpha _ - = ((sum _ (lambda = 1)) ^ ell)@(d _ lambda * q ^ (- lambda)) + (2 * H) ^ (- 1), formulae@(beta _ - = (((sum _ (lambda = 1)) ^ ell)@(d _ lambda * q ^ (- lambda)) + q ^ (- ell)) - (2 * H) ^ (- 1), formulae@(Delta _ - = H ^ (- 1), formulae@(alpha _ + = ((sum _ (lambda = 1)) ^ ell)@(d _ lambda * q ^ (- lambda)) - (2 * H) ^ (- 1), formulae@(beta _ + = ((sum _ (lambda = 1)) ^ ell)@(d _ lambda * q ^ (- lambda)) + q ^ (- ell) + (2 * H) ^ (- 1), Delta _ + = H ^ (- 1))))))

para.p: We apply Lemma with =αβδα-β-δ- and =αβδα+β+δ+, respectively, in order to get two functions I- and I+. By the choices of α±β±δ± it is immediate that
Lemma also implies that these two functions have Fourier expansions

Math.text: I _ plus-or-minus * t = (q ^ (- ell) plus-or-minus H ^ (- 1)) + ((sum _ (list@(nu = - infinity, nu not-equals 0))) ^ infinity)@(A _ plus-or-minus * nu * e * nu * t)
I _ plus-or-minus * t = (q ^ (- ell) plus-or-minus H ^ (- 1)) + ((sum _ (list@(nu = - infinity, nu not-equals 0))) ^ infinity)@(A _ plus-or-minus * nu * e * nu * t)

para.p: satisfying

Math.text: absolute-value@(A _ plus-or-minus * nu) lessless minimum@(open-interval@((absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 1), H * (absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 2)))

para.p: In a next step we want to replace I by I+ in (). For this purpose we observe, using (), that

Math.text: absolute-value@(I * t - I _ + * t) less= absolute-value@(I _ + * t - I _ - * t) lessless H ^ (- 1) + ((sum _ (list@(nu = - infinity, nu not-equals 0))) ^ infinity)@(A _ plus-or-minus * nu * e * nu * t)

para.p: Thus subtracting yields the main part, and summing over ≤pN gives

Math.text: absolute-value@((sum _ (p less= N))@(I * q ^ (- j) * f * p) - (pi * N) / q ^ ell) lessless pi * N * H ^ (- 1) + ((sum _ (list@(nu = - infinity, nu not-equals 0))) ^ infinity)@(A _ plus-or-minus * nu * (sum _ (p less= N))@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * p))

para.p: Now we consider the coefficients ⁢A±ν. Noting () one observes that

Math.text: A _ plus-or-minus * nu lessless cases[[nu ^ (- 1), [for ] * absolute-value@(nu) less= H], [H * nu ^ (- 2), [for ] * absolute-value@(nu) > H]]

para.p: Estimating all summands with >νH trivially we get

Math.text: ((sum _ (list@(nu = - infinity, nu not-equals 0))) ^ infinity)@(A _ plus-or-minus * nu * e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * p) lessless ((sum _ (nu = 1)) ^ H)@(nu ^ (- 1) * e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * p) + H ^ (- 1)

para.p: Using this in () yields

Math.text: absolute-value@((sum _ (p less= N))@(I * q ^ (- j) * f * p) - (pi * N) / q ^ ell) lessless pi * N * H ^ (- 1) + ((sum _ (nu = 1)) ^ H)@(nu ^ (- 1) * (sum _ (p less= N))@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * p))

para.p: Finally we sum over all js and get

Math.text: absolute-value@((sum _ (p less= N))@(N ^ * * f * p) - ((pi * N) / q ^ ell) * J) lessless pi * N * H ^ (- 1) * J + ((sum _ (j = ell)) ^ J)@(((sum _ (nu = 1)) ^ H)@(nu ^ (- 1) * S * vector@(N, j, nu)))

para.p: where we have set

Math.text: S * vector@(N, j, nu) assign (sum _ (p less= N))@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * p)

para.p: The crucial part is the estimation of the exponential sums over the primes. In the following we will distinguish two cases according to the size of j. This corresponds to the position in the expansion of ⁢fp. In particular, let >ρ0 be arbitrarily small then we want to distinguish between the most significant digits and the least significant digits, i.e., between the ranges

Math.text: formulae@(1 less= q ^ j less= N ^ ((theta - 1) + rho), list@([and], N ^ ((theta - 1) + rho)) less q ^ j less= N ^ theta)

para.p: In this subsection we assume that

Math.text: N ^ ((theta - 1) + rho) less q ^ j less= N ^ theta

para.p: which means that we deal with the most significant digits in the expansion. We start by rewriting the sum into an integral.

Math.text: S * vector@(N, j, nu) = (sum _ (p less= N))@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * p) = ((integral _ 2) ^ N)@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * t * d * pi * t) + O * 1
S * vector@(N, j, nu) = (sum _ (p less= N))@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * p) = ((integral _ 2) ^ N)@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * t * d * pi * t) + O * 1

para.p: In the second step we then apply the prime number theorem. Thus

Math.text: S * vector@(N, j, nu) = ((integral _ (N * (logarithm@(N)) ^ (- G))) ^ N)@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * t * ((d * t) / logarithm@(t))) + O * (N / (logarithm@(N)) ^ G)
S * vector@(N, j, nu) = ((integral _ (N * (logarithm@(N)) ^ (- G))) ^ N)@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * t * ((d * t) / logarithm@(t))) + O * (N / (logarithm@(N)) ^ G)

para.p: Now we use the second mean-value theorem together with Lemma and =kθ to get

Math.text: S * vector@(N, j, nu) lessless (1 / logarithm@(N)) * (supremum _ xi)@(absolute-value@(((integral _ (N * (logarithm@(N)) ^ (- G))) ^ xi)@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * t * d * t))) + O * (N / (logarithm@(N)) ^ G) lessless (1 / logarithm@(N)) * (absolute-value@(nu) / q ^ j) ^ (- 1 / k) + O * (N / (logarithm@(N)) ^ G)

para.p: For the digits in this range we want to apply Vaughan’s identity in order to transfer the sum over the primes into two special types of sums involving products of integers. Before we may apply Vaughan’s identity we have to weight the exponential sum under consideration by the von Mangoldt function. By an application of Lemma , it suffices to consider an interval of the form P⁢2P. Thus

Math.text: absolute-value@(S * vector@(N, j, nu)) lessless logarithm@(N) * absolute-value@((sum _ (P less p less= 2 * P))@(e * f * p))

para.p: Using partial summation we get

Math.text: absolute-value@(S * vector@(N, j, nu)) lessless logarithm@(N) * absolute-value@((sum _ (P less p less= 2 * P))@(e * f * p)) lessless logarithm@(N) * P ^ (1 / 2) + logarithm@(N) * absolute-value@((sum _ (P less n less= P _ 1))@(Lambda * n * e * f * n))

para.p: for some P1 with P<P1≤⁢2P. From now on we may assume that >PN-1η.
Then an application of Lemma with =UPδ3, =VP13, =ZP-12δ3 yields

Math.text: S * vector@(N, j, nu) lessless P ^ (1 / 2) + (logarithm@(P)) ^ 7 * absolute-value@(S _ 1)
S * vector@(N, j, nu) lessless P ^ (1 / 2) + (logarithm@(P)) ^ 7 * absolute-value@(S _ 1)

para.p: where S1 is either a Type I sum as in () with ≥YP-12δ3 or a Type II sum as in () with

Math.text: P ^ (delta / 3) less= Y less= P ^ (1 / 3)

para.p: Suppose first that S1 is a Type II sum, i.e.,

Math.text: S _ 1 = (sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(a _ x * (sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(b _ y * e * f * x * y))

para.p: Then an application of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality yields

Math.text: (absolute-value@(S _ 1)) ^ 2 less= (sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@((absolute-value@(a _ x)) ^ 2 * (sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@((absolute-value@((sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(b _ y * e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * x * y))) ^ 2))
(absolute-value@(S _ 1)) ^ 2

absent less= (sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@((absolute-value@(a _ x)) ^ 2 * (sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@((absolute-value@((sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(b _ y * e * (nu / q ^ j) * f * x * y))) ^ 2))

absent lessless X * P ^ (2 * varepsilon) * (sum _ (Y less y less= Y _ 1))@((sum _ (Y less z less= Y _ 1))@(b _ y * overline@(b _ z) * (sum _ (list@(X less x less= X _ 1, formulae@(P less x * y, x * z less= P _ 1))))@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * (f * x * y - f * x * z))))

absent lessless X * P ^ (2 * varepsilon) * (sum _ (Y less y less= Y _ 1))@((sum _ (Y less z less= Y _ 1))@(b _ y * overline@(b _ z) * (sum _ (list@(X less x less= X _ 1, formulae@(P less x * y, x * z less= P _ 1))))@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * (f * x * y - f * x * z))))

para.p: where we have used that ≪axPε. Collecting all the terms where =yz and using ≪byPε yields

Math.text: (absolute-value@(S _ 1)) ^ 2 lessless X * P ^ (4 * varepsilon) * (X * Y + (sum _ (Y less y less z less= Y _ 1))@(absolute-value@((sum _ (list@(X less x less= X _ 1, formulae@(P less x * y, x * z less= P _ 1))))@(e * (nu / q ^ j) * (f * x * y - f * x * z)))))

para.p: There must be a pair yz with Y<y<z<Y1 such that

Math.text: (absolute-value@(S _ 1)) ^ 2 lessless P ^ (2 + 4 * varepsilon) * Y ^ (- 1) + P ^ (4 * varepsilon) * X * Y ^ 2 * absolute-value@((sum _ (X _ 2 less x less= X _ 3))@(e * g * x))

para.p: where =X2maxX⁢Py-1, =X3minX1⁢P1z-1 and

Math.text: g * x = (nu / q ^ j) * (f * x * y - f * x * z) = (nu / q ^ j) * alpha * (y ^ theta - z ^ theta) * x ^ theta

para.p: We will apply Lemma to estimate the exponential sum. Setting

Math.text: k assign ceiling@(2 * theta) + 1

para.p: we get that ∼⁢g+k1x⁢νq-jαθ-θ1⋯-θkx-θ+k1. Thus
or similarly for -⁢g+k1x, where

Math.text: lambda = c * nu * q ^ (- j) * alpha * (y ^ theta - z ^ theta) * X ^ (theta - (k + 1))

para.p: and c depends only on θ and α.
Since >θ1 we get

Math.text: lambda >= P ^ (delta - theta) * Y ^ (theta - 1) * X ^ (theta - (k + 1)) >= X ^ (- k - 1 / 2)

para.p: Similarly we obtain

Math.text: lambda less= P ^ (2 * delta) * Y ^ theta * X ^ (theta - (k + 1)) lessless P ^ (theta + 2 * delta) * X ^ (- (k + 1)) less= X ^ (- 1)

para.p: Thus we get that X--k12≤λ≤X-1. Therefore an application of Lemma yields

Math.text: (sum _ (X _ 2 less x less= X _ 3))@(e * g * x) lessless X ^ (1 - eta)

para.p: where η depends only on k an therefore on θ. Inserting this in () we get

Math.text: (absolute-value@(S _ 1)) ^ 2 lessless P ^ (2 + 4 * varepsilon) * Y ^ (- 1) + P ^ (4 * varepsilon) * X * Y ^ 2 * X ^ (1 - eta) lessless P ^ (2 + 4 * varepsilon) * (P ^ (- delta / 3) + P ^ (- (2 * eta) / 3))

para.p: The case of S1 being a type I sum is similar but simpler. We have

Math.tex: \displaystyle\left|S\right|\leq\sum_{X<x\leq X_{1}}\left|a_{x}\right|\left|% \sum_{\substack{Y<y\leq Y_{1}\\ P<xy\leq P_{1}}}(\log y)e\left(f(xy)\right)\right|\ll XP^{\varepsilon}\left|% \sum_{\substack{Y<y\leq Y_{1}\\ P<xy\leq P_{1}}}(\log y)e\left(f(xy)\right)\right|
Math.text: absolute-value@(S) less= (sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(absolute-value@(a _ x) * absolute-value@((sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(logarithm@(y) * e * f * x * y))) lessless X * P ^ varepsilon * absolute-value@((sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(logarithm@(y) * e * f * x * y))

Math.tex: \displaystyle\left|S\right|\leq\sum_{X<x\leq X_{1}}\left|a_{x}\right|\left|% \sum_{\substack{Y<y\leq Y_{1}\\ P<xy\leq P_{1}}}(\log y)e\left(f(xy)\right)\right|\ll XP^{\varepsilon}\left|% \sum_{\substack{Y<y\leq Y_{1}\\ P<xy\leq P_{1}}}(\log y)e\left(f(xy)\right)\right|
Math.text: absolute-value@(S) less= (sum _ (X less x less= X _ 1))@(absolute-value@(a _ x) * absolute-value@((sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(logarithm@(y) * e * f * x * y))) lessless X * P ^ varepsilon * absolute-value@((sum _ (list@(Y less y less= Y _ 1, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(logarithm@(y) * e * f * x * y))

para.p: for some x with X<x≤X1. By a partial summation we get

Math.text: absolute-value@(S) lessless X * P ^ varepsilon * logarithm@(P * absolute-value@((sum _ (list@(Y _ 2 less y less= Y _ 3, P less x * y less= P _ 1)))@(e * f * x * y)))

para.p: for some Y≤Y2<Y3≤Y1. Now we set

Math.text: g * y = f * x * y = (nu / q ^ j) * alpha * x ^ theta * y ^ theta

para.p: Again the idea is to apply Lemma for the estimation of the exponential sum. We set

Math.text: k assign ceiling@(3 * theta) + 2

para.p: and get for the +k1-st derivative
or similarly for -⁢g+k1x, where

Math.text: lambda = c * (nu / q ^ j) * alpha * x ^ theta * Y ^ (theta - (k + 1))

para.p: and c again depends only on α and θ. We may assume that N and hence P is sufficiently large, then we get that

Math.text: Y ^ (- (k + 1)) lessless P ^ (- theta) * X ^ theta * Y ^ (theta - (k + 1)) less= lambda less= P ^ (2 * delta) * X ^ theta * Y ^ (theta - (k + 1)) lessless P ^ (theta + 2 * delta) * Y ^ (- (k + 1)) less= Y ^ (- 1)

para.p: Now an application of Lemma 2.5 yields

Math.text: (sum _ (Y _ 2 less y less= Y _ 3))@(e * g * y) lessless Y ^ (1 - eta)

para.p: where η depends only on k and thus on θ. Inserting this in () we get

Math.text: absolute-value@(S _ 1) lessless logarithm@(P) * X * P ^ varepsilon * Y ^ (1 - eta) lessless logarithm@(P) * P ^ ((1 + varepsilon) - eta * (1 / 2 - delta / 3))

para.p: Combining () and () in () yields

Math.text: absolute-value@(S * vector@(N, j, nu)) lessless P ^ (1 / 2) + (logarithm@(P)) ^ 7 * (P ^ (1 + 2 * varepsilon) * (P ^ (- delta / 6) + P ^ (- eta / 3)) + logarithm@(P) * P ^ ((1 + varepsilon) - eta * (1 / 2 - delta / 3))) lessless P ^ (1 / 2) + (logarithm@(P)) ^ 8 * P ^ (1 - sigma)

para.p: On the one hand summing () over j and ν yields

Math.text: (sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(nu) less= delta ^ 2))@((absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 1) * (sum _ (N ^ (theta - delta) less q ^ j less= N ^ theta))@(S * vector@(N, j, nu)))
(sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(nu) less= delta ^ 2))@((absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 1) * (sum _ (N ^ (theta - delta) less q ^ j less= N ^ theta))@(S * vector@(N, j, nu)))

lessless (sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(nu) less= delta ^ 2))@((absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 1) * (sum _ (N ^ (theta - delta) less q ^ j less= N ^ theta))@((1 / logarithm@(N)) * (absolute-value@(nu) / q ^ j) ^ (- 1 / k) + O * (N / (logarithm@(N)) ^ G)))

lessless (sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(nu) less= delta ^ 2))@((absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 1) * (sum _ (N ^ (theta - delta) less q ^ j less= N ^ theta))@((1 / logarithm@(N)) * (absolute-value@(nu) / q ^ j) ^ (- 1 / k) + O * (N / (logarithm@(N)) ^ G)))

lessless (1 / logarithm@(N)) * (sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(nu) less= delta ^ 2))@((absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 1 - 1 / k) * (sum _ (N ^ (theta - delta) less q ^ j less= N ^ theta))@(q ^ (- j / k))) + O * (N / (logarithm@(N)) ^ (G - 2))

lessless (1 / logarithm@(N)) * (sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(nu) less= delta ^ 2))@((absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 1 - 1 / k) * (sum _ (N ^ (theta - delta) less q ^ j less= N ^ theta))@(q ^ (- j / k))) + O * (N / (logarithm@(N)) ^ (G - 2))
lessless N / logarithm@(N)
lessless N / logarithm@(N)

para.p: On the other hand in () we sum over j and ν and get

Math.text: (sum _ (1 less= absolute-value@(nu) less= delta ^ 2))@((absolute-value@(nu)) ^ (- 1) * (sum _ (q ^ ell less= q ^ j less= N ^ theta))@(S * vector@(N, j, nu))) lessless (logarithm@(N)) ^ 2 * N ^ (1 / 2) + (logarithm@(N)) ^ 10 * N ^ (1 - sigma ^ prime)

para.p: Combining these estimates in () finally yields

Math.text: absolute-value@((sum _ (p less= N))@(N ^ * * f * p) - ((pi * N) / q ^ ell) * J) lessless N / logarithm@(N)
absolute-value@((sum _ (p less= N))@(N ^ * * f * p) - ((pi * N) / q ^ ell) * J) lessless N / logarithm@(N)

para.p: and the proposition is proved.
The authors thank the anonymous referee, who read very carefully the manuscript and his/her suggestions improve considerably the presentation of the results.
